title: How to Make Traditional Christmas Fudge

steps.headline: Line a pan with aluminum foil and coat it with butter.
steps.description: Get out a 9 in × 9 in (23 cm × 23 cm) pan and tear off a sheet of aluminum foil. Press the foil into the pan so it covers the bottom and sides of the pan. Then rub a little butter over the foil. This will make it easier to remove the fudge. If you prefer thinner fudge, use a 7 ⁄2 in × 11 in (19 cm × 28 cm) pan. If you don't have aluminum foil, substitute waxed paper.

steps.headline: Put the butter, milk, sugar, and salt into a saucepan.
steps.description: Place 2 tablespoons (28 g) of butter into the pan along with ⁄3 cup (160 ml) of evaporated milk, 1 ½ cups (300 g) of granulated sugar, and ¼ teaspoon (1.5 g) of salt. Ensure that you use evaporated milk and not sweetened condensed milk.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil and cook it for 4 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner on to medium and stir the ingredients until they're combined. Keep cooking the mixture and stirring it constantly as it begins to boil. Stir and boil it for 4 minutes. The fudge mixture will thicken a little as some of the moisture evaporates.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and stir in marshmallows, chocolate, vanilla, and nuts.
steps.description: Stir 2 cups (100 g) of miniature marshmallows or 18 large chopped marshmallows, 1 ½ cups (270 g) of semisweet chocolate chips or chunks, and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract. For traditional Christmas fudge, stir in ½ cup (55 g) of chopped nuts, such as walnuts or pecans. Stir well until the marshmallows melt.Variation: Experiment by using your favorite nuts, such as hazelnuts or almonds. You can also try using white chocolate instead of semisweet, if you prefer a sweeter fudge. You shouldn't see any lumps in your fudge mixture. Keep stirring until the marshmallow lumps have melted.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into the pan.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and immediately pour the hot mixture into your prepared pan. Use the back of a spoon or offset spatula to spread the mixture so it's level. This is especially important if you want smooth, even squares of fudge. If you prefer a rustic, swirled look, don't smooth down the fudge very much. Sprinkle extra chopped nuts over the top of the fudge if you'd like extra crunch.

steps.headline: Chill the fudge until it hardens before you cut it into pieces.
steps.description: Cover the pan with plastic wrap and refrigerate it for about 2 hours so the fudge becomes firm. If you're short on time, put it in the freezer for 30 minutes. Once the fudge has set, carefully lift it out of the pan and place it on a cutting board. Cut the fudge into squares that are around 1 inch (2.5 cm). Put the leftover fudge in an airtight container and store it at room temperature for up to 2 weeks. For longer storage, refrigerate it for up to 3 to 4 weeks.

steps.headline: Line a pan with aluminum foil and grease it.
steps.description: Get out a 8 in × 8 in (20 cm × 20 cm) pan and tear off a sheet of aluminum foil that will cover the bottom and sides of the pan. Push the foil into the pan and spray it with nonstick cooking spray or rub a little butter over it. Set the pan aside while you make the fudge. If you prefer thinner fudge, use a 9 in × 9 in (23 cm × 23 cm) pan. Try using waxed paper or parchment paper if you don't have aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Melt the chocolate, milk, molasses, and butter over medium heat.
steps.description: Put 3 cups (525 g) of white chocolate chips into a saucepan along with a 14-ounce (396 g) can of sweetened condensed milk, 1/4 cup (80 g) of molasses, and 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter. Turn the burner on to medium and stir occasionally until the chocolate melts. Stirring every once in a while will prevent the mixture from sticking to the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and stir in the spices and vanilla.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract to the fudge mixture along with 1 1/2 teaspoon (3 g) of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground cinnamon, 3/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) of ground nutmeg, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of allspice, and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cloves. Stir until the spices are incorporated. Feel free to play around with the spices. For example, if you don't like the taste of allspice, leave it out or add the same amount of a spice that you do like, such as nutmeg.

steps.headline: Spread the fudge in the pan.
steps.description: Quickly and carefully pour the hot fudge mixture into the prepared pan. For smooth fudge, level the fudge with the back of a spoon or an offset spatula. If you prefer swirled fudge, leave the top of the fudge with slight peaks.Variation: For a festive decoration, sprinkle 1/2 tablespoon of red nonpareils and 1/2 tablespoon of green nonpareils over the top of the fudge before it sets.

steps.headline: Chill the fudge for 1 to 2 hours before you cut it.
steps.description: Cover the pan with plastic wrap and put it in the fridge until it hardens. If you prefer to leave the fudge at room temperature, leave it for 3 to 4 hours so it sets. Then cut the fudge into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces. Store the leftover fudge in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks or refrigerate it for up to 3 to 4 weeks.

steps.headline: Lay a piece of waxed paper in an 8 in × 8 in (20 cm × 20 cm) pan.
steps.description: Tear off a sheet of waxed paper and place it in the pan. The waxed paper should extend over the sides of the pan. This will make it easy to lift the fudge out of the pan once it's hardened. If you don't have waxed paper, use parchment paper or greased aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Melt the chocolate chips until they're smooth.
steps.description: To quickly melt the white chocolate chips, pour a 12-ounce (340 g) package of white chocolate chips into a microwave-safe bowl. Microwave the chocolate in 30-second increments and stir it frequently so the chocolate melts. If you prefer, put the chips into a double boiler and heat them on the stove until they melt.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and stir in the frosting and peppermint extract.
steps.description: Scoop a 16-ounce (453 g) container of vanilla frosting into the melted white chocolate. Add ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of peppermint extract and stir until they're combined. Play around with different flavors of fudge by changing the frosting flavor. For example, use chocolate or cream cheese frosting instead.

steps.headline: Spread the fudge in the pan and squirt the food coloring across the top.
steps.description: Use the back of a spoon or offset spatula to make the fudge level in the pan. Then squeeze 8 drops of red food coloring evenly over the fudge. You can leave out the food coloring if you want pale peppermint fudge with no swirl.

steps.headline: Drag a knife through the top of the fudge to swirl the coloring.
steps.description: Use a figure-8 motion to create red swirls through the peppermint fudge. For finer swirls, use a skewer instead of a knife. The more you swirl the fudge, the more combined the fudge will become. This will make the fudge pink in color and the swirls will be less defined.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the candy on top and chill the fudge for 1 hour.
steps.description: Scatter 2 tablespoons (25 g) of crushed peppermint candies evenly over the fudge and cover the pan with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the fudge until it's firm enough to cut into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces.Tip: To crush your own peppermint candies, take a mini-candy cane or half of a standard candy cane and place it on a clean kitchen towel. Fold the towel over and bang a rolling pin over it to crush the candy. To store leftover fudge, put it into an airtight container. Keep it at room temperature for up to 2 weeks or refrigerate it for up to 3 to 4 weeks.
